title: United States energy independence
text:
US energy independence is the idea of eliminating the need for the <a href="Energy%20in%20the%20United%20States">United States</a> to import petroleum and other foreign sources of energy, either entirely or with the exception of imports from <a href="Energy%20in%20Canada">Canada</a> and <a href="Energy%20in%20Mexico">Mexico</a>, in which case it is called North American energy independence. <a href="Energy%20independence">Energy independence</a> is espoused by those who want to leave the US unaffected by global energy <a href="supply%20chain">supply</a> disruptions, and to restrict reliance upon <a href="Fragile%20state">politically unstable states</a> for its <a href="energy%20security">energy security</a>. Energy independence is highly concerned with <a href="Petroleum">oil</a>, the source of the country's principal <a href="transport%20fuel">transport fuel</a>s.
In total energy consumption, the US was between 86% and 91% <a href="Autarky">self-sufficient</a> in 2016. In May 2011, the country became a net exporter of <a href="Oil%20refinery">refined</a> petroleum products. By 2014, the United States was world's <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20oil%20production">third largest producer of crude oil</a>, after Saudi Arabia and Russia, and second-largest exporter of refined products, after Russia. In November 2019, the United States became a net exporter of all oil products, including both refined petroleum products and crude oil. By 2021 the US was the world's largest producer.
As of March 2015, 85% of crude oil imports came from (in decreasing volume): Canada, <a href="Energy%20in%20Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, Mexico, <a href="Energy%20in%20Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, and <a href="Electricity%20sector%20in%20Colombia">Colombia</a>. Nineteen percent of imported oil came from <a href="Energy%20in%20the%20Middle%20East">the Middle East</a>. The fraction of crude oil consumed in the US that was imported went from 35% immediately before the <a href="1973%20oil%20crisis">1973 oil crisis</a>, peaked at 60% in 2005, and then returned to 35% by 2013 thanks to increased domestic production from the <a href="tight%20oil">shale oil</a> boom. Beginning in the 1970s, exports of crude oil were illegal without a permit; in 2013, the United States physically exported a relatively small amount of oil, and only to Canada. The ban was repealed in 2015.
Greater energy self-sufficiency, it was claimed, would prevent major <a href="Energy%20crisis">supply disruptions</a> like the <a href="1973%20oil%20crisis">1973 oil crisis</a> and the <a href="1979%20energy%20crisis">1979 energy crisis</a> from recurring. Proponents argue that the potential for political unrest in major oil suppliers, such as <a href="Oil%20reserves%20in%20Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="Oil%20reserves%20in%20Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, and <a href="Petroleum%20industry%20in%20Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, is abundant, and often causes great fluctuations in crude <a href="Price%20of%20oil">oil prices</a> (especially in the short term).
Large individual <a href="Natural%20gas%20pipeline%20system%20in%20the%20United%20States">US pipelines</a> and other fuel infrastructure and extraction projects are <a href="Energy%20Politics">controversial issues in US politics</a>.
Historical trend.
In the early 20th century the United States became a major oil supplier to the world. World War II prompted a <a href="Synthetic%20Liquid%20Fuels%20Program">Synthetic Liquid Fuels Program</a> but it did not go beyond research. In mid-century the country shifted from being a major exporter to a net importer. An <a href="import%20quota">import quota</a> imposed in 1959 (during the <a href="Presidency%20of%20Dwight%20D.%20Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower administration</a>) limited imports to a fraction of domestic production until 1973. After the <a href="1973%20oil%20crisis">1973 oil crisis</a>, the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Energy">United States Department of Energy</a> and <a href="Synthetic%20Fuels%20Corporation">Synthetic Fuels Corporation</a> were created to address the problem of fuel import dependency.
The US's dependence on foreign oil rose from 26 percent to 47 percent between 1985 and 1989.
According to the <a href="Washington%20%26amp%3B%20Jefferson%20College%20Energy%20Index">Washington & Jefferson College Energy Index</a>, by 2012, American energy independence had decreased by 22% since the <a href="Presidency%20of%20Harry%20Truman">Presidency of Harry Truman</a>. The US's imports of foreign oil fell to 36 percent in 2013 (during the <a href="Presidency%20of%20Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama administration</a>), down from a high of 60 percent in 2006 (during the <a href="Presidency%20of%20George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush administration</a>).
Many proponents of energy independence look to the <a href="Oil%20reserves%20in%20the%20United%20States">United States' untapped domestic oil reserves</a>, either known or potential. Those who favor increasing domestic oil production often suggest removing many of the limitations on oil exploration in the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>, the <a href="Arctic%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge">Arctic National Wildlife Refuge</a> (see <a href="Arctic%20Refuge%20drilling%20controversy">Arctic Refuge drilling controversy</a>) and the outer <a href="continental%20shelf">continental shelf</a>. Foreign dependence is not the only factor in North American <a href="Petroleum%20politics">energy politics</a>, however; <a href="Environmental%20impact%20of%20the%20energy%20industry">environmental concerns around land and water pollution</a> and <a href="greenhouse%20gas">greenhouse gas</a>es are also matters of controversy.
Approaches.
Some proponents of US energy independence promote wider use of alternatives such as <a href="ethanol%20fuel">ethanol fuel</a>, <a href="methanol">methanol</a>, <a href="biodiesel">biodiesel</a>, <a href="plug-in%20hybrid">plug-in hybrid</a>s and other <a href="alternative%20propulsion">alternative propulsion</a>. A 2013 report published by the <a href="Fuel%20Freedom%20Foundation">Fuel Freedom Foundation</a> said that without a shift to domestic <a href="feedstock">feedstock</a>s for fuel, such as natural gas and <a href="biomass">biomass</a>, the US would not be able to achieve energy independence. As of 2014, the United States imposed an import tariff of 54 cents a gallon on ethanol fuel (there is no such import tariff on oil or <a href="methanol%20fuel">methanol fuel</a>). <a href="Ethanol%20fuel%20in%20Brazil">Ethanol fuel in Brazil</a> is produced from <a href="sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, which yields much more fuel per acre than the corn used for ethanol production in the United States.
In the United States, oil is primarily consumed as fuel for cars, buses, trucks and airplanes (in the form of gasoline, diesel and <a href="jet%20fuel">jet fuel</a>). Two thirds of US oil consumption is due to the transportation sector. A national strategy designed to shift all transportation to a combined use of alternative fuels and plug-in hybrids is predicted to make the US independent of petroleum (oil).
North American energy independence.
Oil imports are most problematic in domestic politics and energy security when they come from countries that are openly hostile to <a href="US%20foreign%20policy">US foreign policy</a> and interests (<a href="Iran%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">Iran</a>, <a href="United%20States%E2%80%93Venezuela%20relations">Venezuela</a>, and formerly <a href="Iraq%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">Iraq</a>), are former or potential future rivals (<a href="Russia%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">Russia</a>) or have questionable human rights practices (<a href="Human%20rights%20in%20Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>). Sometimes an alternative "North American energy independence" is proposed, by which North America as a unit should be energy independent, but in which the US could still import energy from Canada and Mexico, which are less problematic allies and more tightly economically integrated.
A related, less absolute, policy may be called "North American energy security". In 2012 in an editorial to Canadian newspaper "<a href="The%20Globe%20and%20Mail">The Globe and Mail</a>" Mexican president elect <a href="Enrique%20Pe%C3%B1a%20Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a>, called North American energy security a "common goal" of Canada and Mexico.
The benefits are argued to be similar to US energy independence—the reduction of North America's energy dependence on unstable regions such as the Middle East and South America and accepting supplies from the reliable <a href="North%20American%20Free%20Trade%20Area">North American Free Trade Area</a>, reducing exposure to terrorism abroad; lower <a href="balance%20of%20trade">balance of trade</a> and <a href="Foreign%20exchange%20market">foreign exchange</a> stresses on the <a href="U.S.%20economy">US economy</a> in an era when suppliers may begin to price oil in <a href="euro">euro</a>s; the development of <a href="renewable%20energy">renewable energy</a> sources to displace <a href="fossil%20fuel">fossil fuel</a>s; and the promotion of <a href="energy%20conservation">energy conservation</a> technology exportable to energy-poor nations.
Programs to limit US energy interests by Canada and Mexico.
In Canada and Mexico there is also the concern not to have energy policy dictated by the United States, as well as tension over US ownership of energy companies.
In 1937 Mexico passed a constitutional amendment to <a href="Nationalization">nationalize</a> its oil industry, which led to the creation of <a href="Pemex">Pemex</a>, the <a href="national%20oil%20company">national oil company</a>. There have been several proposals to privatize Pemex since, but they have never come to fruition as many Mexicans fear foreign control of this strategic industry.
The <a href="1957%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1957 Canadian election</a> was fought partially in response to the 1956 <a href="Pipeline%20Debate">Pipeline Debate</a> which concerned whether or not the government should allow a US-owned company to build a <a href="TransCanada%20pipeline">trans-Canadian gas pipeline</a> and whether the route should be entirely within Canada or partly through the United States. The right-leaning <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Canada">Progressive Conservatives</a> and leftist <a href="Co-operative%20Commonwealth%20Federation">Co-operative Commonwealth Federation</a> opposition parties opposed American involvement in the pipeline while the Liberal government supported it. The Liberals were defeated in the 1957 election.
In 1973 Canada created its own state energy company <a href="Petro-Canada">Petro-Canada</a>. It began operations in 1976, though it bought assets from private companies rather than seizing them as in many other countries. In 1980 the <a href="National%20Energy%20Program">National Energy Program</a> was launched to create oil self-sufficiency within Canada. It attempted to use tax incentives to discourage oil exports (mostly from Western Canada, primarily the province of <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a>) to the US, and redirect these towards to the oil importing provinces of Eastern Canada. The <a href="Foreign%20Investment%20Review%20Agency">Foreign Investment Review Agency</a> was also created to screen foreign (mostly US) takeovers of Canadian companies. These policies were bitterly opposed by the provincial government of Alberta, and were repealed and reversed during the Conservative government of 1984–1993 which sought closer economic ties with the US, including the <a href="Canada%E2%80%93US%20Free%20Trade%20Agreement">Canada–US Free Trade Agreement</a> of 1988.
U.S. Presidential views.
Carter Administration.
In his <a href="Presidency%20of%20Jimmy%20Carter%23Malaise%20speech">Malaise speech</a>, President <a href="Jimmy%20Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> declared that "the United States will never again import as much oil as it did in 1977" (<a href="Jimmy%20Carter">Carter</a>),
Bush Administration.
In his 2006 <a href="State%20of%20the%20Union%20Address">State of the Union Address</a>, President <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush</a> used the phrase "addicted to oil", a phrase widely discussed in the media.
Oil imports into the US peaked in 2006, when imports supplied nearly 12 million barrels/day which is 60% of US consumption; they have declined since, due both to increased domestic oil production, and reduced consumption.
Obama administration.
In 2011, President <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> released his "Blueprint for a Secure Energy Future" that aimed to reduce oil dependence by a third, by producing more oil at domestically, increasing use of cleaner alternative fuels, and greater efficiency. Obama stated "the fact of the matter is, is that for quite some time, America is going to be still dependent on oil in making its economy work."
In 2012, Obama repeatedly stated that the US had begun "freeing ourselves from foreign oil." Canadian observers noted that his usage of "foreign" did not include Canada. Obama called Canada and Mexico "stable" foreign energy suppliers.
Keystone XL Pipeline - Obama vs. Trump.
The <a href="Keystone%20XL%20pipeline">Keystone XL pipeline</a> from <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a> to the <a href="Gulf%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">Gulf Coast</a> would expedite processing of Canadian oil. In November 2015, Obama rejected the proposal to build this pipeline because of domestic environmental concerns over water quality as well as the general antipathy of the <a href="environmental%20movement">environmental movement</a> to pipeline building, and the production practices in the source (the <a href="Athabasca%20oil%20sands">Athabasca oil sands</a>).
In March 2017, <a href="President%20Donald%20J.%20Trump">President Donald J. Trump</a> announced the granting of a permit for construction of the <a href="Keystone%20Pipeline">Keystone XL</a> pipeline, calling it "the first of many infrastructure projects" that he intended to approve in order to put more Americans to work. The permitting came two months after Trump, only days into his presidency, signed an <a href="executive%20order">executive order</a> aimed at reviving the Keystone XL and <a href="Dakota%20Access%20Pipeline">Dakota Access</a> pipelines.
Trump administration.
In May 2017, <a href="President%20Donald%20J.%20Trump">President Donald J. Trump</a> promised "complete" independence from foreign sources of oil.
During his administration's "Energy Week" celebration of June 2017, President Trump announced that he was formally seeking a review of US energy policies, in order to help the <a href="Nuclear%20power">Nuclear power</a> industry prosper. Trump also announced that the <a href="Interior%20Department">Interior Department</a> would be kicking off the formal process to expand areas available for offshore drilling of oil and natural gas. He vowed to create "American energy dominance".
In May 2018, it was reported that US liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports had quadrupled. The value of US LNG exports was estimated to reach nearly $5 billion in 2018 and $12 billion in 2019.
In early December 2018, it was reported that the US had turned into a net exporter of oil "last week", thus breaking nearly 75 continuous years of dependence on foreign oil. Reportedly, the US sold overseas a net of 211,000 barrels a day of crude and refined products such as gasoline and diesel. This, compared to net imports of about three million barrels a day on average previously during 2018 and the prior annual peak of more than 12 million barrels a day during 2005, was confirmed by the US <a href="Energy%20Information%20Administration">Energy Information Administration</a>.
In March 2019, crude oil prices regained momentum after reports showed an unexpected drop in US fuel supplies. The <a href="American%20Petroleum%20Institute">American Petroleum Institute</a> reported domestic crude inventories declined 2.58 million barrels the previous week. The US Energy Information Administration was due to report on the official numbers on domestic supply and demand. However, James Williams, president at WTRG Economics in London, Arkansas said, "These are clearly bullish numbers, and if reinforced it will be more bullish".
Benefits of oil dependence.
In a 2012 poll of energy experts by "<a href="Foreign%20Policy">Foreign Policy</a>" magazine, almost two-thirds of respondents said energy independence was not a sensible goal.
Highlighting the difficulty of separating domestic and foreign oil sources, journalist Robert Bryce stated in 2008 that "the trends of energy interdependence are growing and are inexorable" and branded the idea of being able to choose where your oil came from as "hogwash".
The structure of the argument of critics is arranged as follows:
In 2008, Roger Howard has argued in "<a href="The%20Wall%20Street%20Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a>" that oil dependence has significant benefits for the US and other oil-importing nations. First, the world's major oil exporters are highly dependent on their oil revenues, and fear rapid drops in the <a href="price%20of%20oil">price of oil</a>, such as occurred in late 2008 and in 2014/2015. Second, this fear restrains destructive actions by exporters: Howard cites the example of Russia's 2008 invasion of <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>. Russia's stock market plunged, and "within a week capital outflow reached a massive $16 billion, suddenly squeezing domestic credit while the ruble collapsed in value." He also gives the example of <a href="Libya">Libya</a>, where <a href="Muammar%20Gaddafi">Muammar al-Gaddafi</a> gave up his <a href="Disarmament%20of%20Libya">nuclear weapon program</a> in exchange for the US lifting its <a href="economic%20sanctions">economic sanctions</a>, which had prevented Libya from increasing its oil production.
In 2008, <a href="Andy%20Grove">Andy Grove</a> argued that energy independence is a <a href="wikt%3Aflawed">flawed</a> and <a href="wikt%3Ainfeasible">infeasible</a> objective, particularly in a network of integrated <a href="World%20economy">global exchange</a>. He suggests instead that the objective should be <a href="energy%20resilience">energy resilience</a>: resilience goes hand in hand with adaptability, and it also is reflected in important market ideas like <a href="Substitute%20good">substitutability</a>. Resilience is one of the best features of <a href="Market%20economy">market processes</a>; the information transmission function of prices means that individual buyers and sellers can adapt to changes in supply and demand conditions in a decentralized way. His suggestion for how to increase the <a href="Resilience%20%28organizational%29">resilience</a> of the US energy economy is to shift use from petroleum to electricity (<a href="electrification">electrification</a>), that can be produced using multiple sources of energy, including <a href="renewable%20source">renewables</a>.
Green Energy.
In 2008, former vice president <a href="Al%20Gore">Al Gore</a> challenged the United States to commit to producing <a href="all%20electricity%20from%20renewable%20sources">all electricity from renewable sources</a> (AERS) like solar and wind power in 10 years. Both the <a href="Center%20for%20Resource%20Solutions">Center for Resource Solutions</a> and former president <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> have publicly stated they support Al Gore's AERS goal.
Canada is the world's second largest producer of hydroelectricity (after China) and exported three billion dollars worth of electricity to the US in 2015, mostly from the major hydro-producing provinces of Québec, Ontario, Manitoba and British Columbia.
